text: Looking at the past tenses, the line in the past and the dot in the past, the line in the past is extremely regular.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We only have a few odd irregular verbs for the line in the past.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Ser is one of them and we can remember by thinking of an era.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So what is the base for ser as a line in the past?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this means I was, you formal were, he, she, it was as a line in the past.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say we were?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: They were or you guys were?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We had the line in the past of ir, which was a little bit like a mix between the aba ending that we have for our verbs for the line in the past and the ia ending that we have for our ir verbs in the line in the past.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So what was I was going from ir?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then we had ver to see.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How is I see in the present?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And this extra e that it keeps for the I form in the present?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Carries over into the line in the past.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So I was seeing, you formal were seeing, he, she, it was seeing is veía.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So the line in the past is a very safe tense.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We just have a few irregular verbs, but for the rest, we can be very certain that taking off the ar and putting aba or taking off the er ir and putting ia is going to give us the result that we want.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The point in the past is less regular, less reliable.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: There are a group of verbs in the dot or point in the past which are irregular, but they all do something very similar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, most of the verbs in this group are got verbs, but not all of them.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, what these verbs do in the point in the past is that firstly the beginning bit of the verb.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So for example, if we have poder, that beginning bit, pod, changes.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We saw, for example, they were able was pudieron.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So that pod changes to pud.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Here it's a little change, but there are more drastic changes with other verbs.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this is the first thing.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The base of the verb that is left once we take the endings off changes.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Sometimes radically, sometimes a little bit like here from pod to pud.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The second thing that they do is that they use a mixture of the point endings from ar verbs and from er ir verbs.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: They use a mixture of the two endings from both sides, but always the same mixture for each of these irregular verbs.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And the third thing they do is to not have the accent on the endings.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So firstly, let's revise the point in the past with hablar and comer, just to refresh what are these endings.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we have hablar, to speak, and I spoke is?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And he spoke or she spoke or you formal spoke?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then we had to eat, which was comer.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And he ate or she ate or you ate?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And you informal spoke, which in the you informal version, we hear that informal s and the informal t in the ending.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: They ate or you guys ate?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So that's the panorama of our dot in the past.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But these irregular verbs use a mixture of these two groups for different endings in the point in the past.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, tener, to have, in the point in the past, the way that ten changes, that root changes, we said that's the first thing that happens.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The ten of tener becomes tuv.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And he, she, it had is tuva.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we're not accenting the endings.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So where are these two endings coming from?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Are they coming from the ar verbs or from the er, ir verbs?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we have tuve and tuvo.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So these two endings for I and for he, she, it, you formal come from ar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And the rest come from er, ir.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say we had with the point in the past?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So now that we've worked our way through this one verb, all we need to do for the other ones is to find the base, the irregular base for the verb and then we know what to do with it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What was to be for states?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now I was, the point in the past from estar is estuve.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So it's nice to look at tener and estar together because we have tuve for I had and estuve for I was.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: He was, she was, you were formal?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So whilst we have these irregular forms which need a little bit more effort, many times you can just use the line in the past instead.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So if you say something like Donde estuviste?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And here we're using a point in time.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So maybe it sounds like where were you in this precise moment when we needed you.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But even so we could still just use the line in the past to get around this irregular tense.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now we don't want to avoid it forever.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Anything that we don't control of the language will end up controlling us.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Anything we are uncertain of that we don't take the control of will control us.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But many times you're in a conversation and you don't have time to find that irregular form and maybe you want to worry about it later and check and think about what it was.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In that case you can just turn to the line in the past Donde estabas instead of Donde estuviste.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say I had to go using this point in the past?

text: So how is I had using the point in the past?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But you could also use the line in the past and not have any problem there if you wanted to avoid this irregular tense just to get the meaning across.
